div1.p: Reed lightheartedly responds to Blincoe's unease about his health, and relates news of family and work. [Courtesy of the Library of Virginia]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, September 26, 1894
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Septr 26, '94
My darling Sister:
div1.p:
I am a
pretty poor kind of a
correspondent, I must
acknowledge - I did get
your letter and I was
away from the City at
the time I received it-
Am sorry to have to
tell you that you in=
terpreted your dream
incorrectly! “Dreams al=
ways go by contraries”.
Had you dreamed that I
was a very stout and
florid individual weigh=
ing 442 lbs, and consuming
36 lbs. of rare beef-steak
at a single sitting, it
would have then, indeed,
been time enough for you
to feel uneasy - As it was,
I have never felt better
in my life than during
this month of September.
You have been overloading
your stomach - a little Blue=
Mass would clear up
the future immensely.
Freeze on to your little
“Mousies” & I will send for
some after a while -
But seriously, I was only
encouraging little Walter.
I don't think that mouse-
culture is exactly the
profession that you
should adopt - No, this
goes against the grain!
I can stand a good
many things, but I can't
yield to the idea of you
cultivating rodents!
I don't want to discour=
age you, but you must
turn it over to one
of the little ones.

Sister E. Blossom & I left
the City on the 1st of Septr
Went up into the moun=
tain, looking for ozone.
Found lots of it and
good appetites too - I
came back on 15th -
They return on 29th - I
now begin hard and in=
cessant work till June
15th 95 - One of my pupils
is sitting on the other side of
my desk, looking at me as
much as to say, “Oh! do pray
stop writing and come and tell
me some thing about this con=
founded bug.” So, I must stop-
Love to all - Don't pay any
attention to dreams - They are all “bosh”
